The Frist Art Museum opened in April 2001, and since that time has hosted a spectacular array of art from the region and from around the world.
The Parthenon stands proudly as the centerpiece of Centennial Park, Nashville\'s premier urban park. Originally built for Tennessee\'s 1897 Centennial Exposition.
The Tennessee Central Railway Museum is dedicated to the preservation of Tennessee\'s railroad heritage. http://www.tcry.org/
Also known as Tootsie\'s World Famous Orchid Lounge, where performers have taken the stage since the early 1960s in hopes of being discovered.

This place is hallowed ground. This is the exact spot where bluegrass was born—where Johnny Cash met June Carter, where souls were saved and a slice of history was nearly lost. It was right here that country music found an audience beyond its own back porch, and countless careers took off as deals were signed on napkins and paper scraps backstage. https://ryman.com http://www.cafelula.net/

HERE there’s a strict no-holds-barred-policy, where you have permission to forget the world outside and get lost — IN the music, ON the dance floor, or WITH the taste of our award-winning BBQ. https://wildhorsesaloon.com/

The stars on the Walk of Fame, spanning genres and generations, honor those that make, create, record, perform, and present music to and for the world. http://www.visitmusiccity.com/walkoffame/
Cheekwood offers many diverse experiences, but a singularly serene environment that will leave you restored and rejuvenated.
Nashville Zoo\'s experienced staff is actively involved in research, habitat protection, breeding programs and education initiatives around the globe as well as in our own backyard.

General Jackson was named after another riverboat of the same name that was built in 1817; that boat was in turn named for Andrew Jackson. The modern boat was originally an attraction at the Opryland USA theme park. The park closed in 1997, but the boat remains in service, docking at Pennington Bend near the Opry Mills shopping center that replaced the park.

Located in the shadow of the Capitol in downtown Nashville, visitors can experience many facets of Tennessee’s history including a 200-foot granite map of the state, a World War II Memorial, a 95-Bell Carillon, a Pathway of History and the Rivers of Tennessee Fountains.
Since 1961, we\'ve been serving scratch-made pancakes and much more to visitors and locals alike in the Hillsboro Village neighborhood. http://www.thepancakepantry.com/

For more than 65 years, the Loveless Cafe has been offering families and friends a place where they can enjoy a home-cooked, Southern meal and reconnect with each other around the table. https://www.lovelesscafe.com
Fido blurs the line between upscale coffeehouse and casual restaurant with an emphasis on organic and local foods served in an inviting atmosphere. http://www.fidonashville.com/
Sambuca, Nashville’s only rockin’ restaurant, features a savory new American menu and a variety of nightly live music. http://www.nashville.sambucarestaurant.com/

Yazoo Brewing really started with a homebrewing kit bought from the back pages of Rolling Stone in 1993. In October 2003, we opened the doors and began selling kegs of Yazoo Pale Ale, Dos Perros, Spring Wheat, and Onward Stout to local bars and restaurants, quickly gaining an enthusiastic local following. http://www.yazoobrew.com/
Founded with the discovery that great beer can be brewed at home, what began as a kitchen hobby amongst friends ultimately transformed into something much greater. http://www.tnbrew.com/
We have been brewing Craft beer in Nashville since 1994. We are Nashville\'s oldest and most award winning brewery. https://blackstonebeer.com/
Has a catalog of several ale recipes that are available year round and seasonally.

Geography. 
Nashville is the capital of Tennessee. 
Founded 1779 
Incorporated 1806

The town of Nashville was founded by James Robertson, John Donelson, and a party of Overmountain Men in 1779, near the original Cumberland settlement of Fort Nashborough. It was named for Francis Nash, the American Revolutionary War hero. Nashville quickly grew because of its strategic location, accessibility as a port on the Cumberland River, a tributary of the Ohio River; and its later status as a major railroad center. \nBy 1800, the city had 345 residents, including 136 enslaved African Americans and 14 free African American residents. In 1806, Nashville was incorporated as a city and became the county seat of Davidson County, Tennessee. In 1843, the city was named the permanent capital of the state of Tennessee.\n
